messages: a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:42): What's the rationale for the "If the charset attribute is specified, the element must be the first element in the head element of the file." requirement in the current spec?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:44): Because if you change charset, it can change the meaning of a previous element
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:44): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: to make the parser restart as early as possible
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:48): So what do current parsers do for instances where the meta@charset or meta@http-equiv=Content-Type is not the first element in the head?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:49): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: they restart later
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:49): Unless the charset claims to be utf-16
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:49): (but that's unrelated)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:50): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: must be first is a doc conformance req
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:50): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: so docs that don't conform still work but give worse browser performance
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:50): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: don't they still restart but as UTF-8?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:52): Might be, I don't have perfect information available

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:55): I think that the requirement to have it be the first element in the head is not going to be intuitive to users so conformance checkers should ideally have an explicit message making it clear that it needs to be.

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:55): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 - validator.nu currently doesn't seem to produce a useful error message for the case if it's not the first element in the head
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:56): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: did you try with charset='' or the HTML4 syntax?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:57): with charset=''

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:11): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 - for validator.nu/?out=text output for valid documents, I wonder whether it shouldn't better emit nothing at all rather than "The document is valid HTML5..."
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:11): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: out=text is supposed to be human-readable
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:12): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: for emacs parsing, I want to have out=gnu
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:12): but the gnu spec is bad
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:12): yeah, it is
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:12): I suppose I could just bite the bullet and hard-code "-" as the file name to sidestep the issue of putting URIs in the gnu format
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (12:13): gnum - gnu umproved
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:13): and to use the v.nu style of column counting instead of what gnu specifies
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:14): most of the time people wouldn't notice...
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:14): but then there are always those edge cases...
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:14): I wonder what other apps do now when they need to include URIs in gnu-style error messages and still want they to be parse-able
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:15): we need GNU error format 5
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:16): hmm. validating the html5 spec even locally is very, very slow
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:17): I wonder if my show source impl is bad or whether I've changed something in the schematron schema that makes the xslt impl go crazy
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:17): or if it is just that Xalan is much much slower than Saxon
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:19): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 - I think Xalan is significantly slower than Saxon

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:27): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: I suppose going back to Saxon for non-Debian installations would make sense then if Saxon were modified to support column numbers in addition to line numbers
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:29): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 - yeah, I think that would be good
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:30): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 - but are you talking about Saxon 6 or later Saxon (8 or 9)?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:31): Saxon 6 is in right in libs in Debian
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:31): not in non-free
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:31): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: 6. using 8 would also involve getting rid of the XSLT 1.0 warning
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:31): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: hmm. that seems like a violation of Debian's own policy...
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:32): dunno. There's even a GCJ version of Saxon packaged for Debian
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:34): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: interesting given the whole Debian vs. pre-tri-license Mozilla thing
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:35): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: and the debial-legal stance of CDDL
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:35): I'd guess Saxon just flew under the debia-legal radar, but I don't know.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:35): yeah, me neither
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:35): hmm. typoed debian twice...
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (12:38): publication in five days, nice
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (12:39): wonders how confusingly the publication will be reported by news sources
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (12:40): At least one will say the spec has been published, in a way that suggests it's complete
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:40): the perf problem definitely is the Schematron part--not show source...
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:43): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 - source for HTML5 spec is still only around 2MB?
